DOC.HEAD: Mail Bomb Probe Unveils Racist Plot, Fears and Uncertainty
Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `The desegregation...' to DELETE reference to threat being made Saturday as it happened earlier but was made public Saturday. Picks up 9th graf pvs, ``We did...'
DOC.TEXT: Two frantic weeks of investigating a series of mail bombs that killed a judge and a civil rights leader have produced shadowy outlines of a racist plot against the judicial system, but uncertainty about who is responsible and when another attack could come. A person or group calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System claimed responsibility for killing U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance on Dec. 16 and Savannah, Ga., lawyer and civil rights leader Robert Robinson two days later. A letter to an Atlanta television station last week threatened stepped-up violence and claimed the justice system was lenient toward blacks who attack whites. ``Protecting the innocent warrants a higher court priority ... than granting the blacks' demand for white teachers for their children,'' the letter said. FBI agents wouldn't say what leads they have gotten from bomb fragments and a hot line set up for tips. They also would not discuss a published report that the letter to the TV station contained an identifying code identical to one in follow-up letters sent to the bomb targets. But agents confirmed the letters contained information known only to investigators and whomever was involved in the bombings. Authorities said they had never heard of Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System, but the threats have been taken seriously around the Southeast. An anchorwoman who received the letter sent to Atlanta station WAGA received police protection. An NAACP official involved in a 21-year-old school desegregation case mentioned in that letter said the FBI warned him he might be a target. The desegregation case involves the DeKalb County schools, and a telephone caller to the bomb hotline threatened DeKalb police earlier in the week. ``We did have a call from the FBI telling us they had some information and we should alert our officers to use extreme caution and to be extremely alert,'' said Margaret Jones, spokeswoman for the 650-officer department. She would not elaborate on what the caller threatened. The 600 Southeastern branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are all taking precautions, said regional director Earl Shinhoster. He would not elaborate, but mentioned that police escorted him on and off a plane when he went to Savannah. Security also is being bolstered for the Jan. 15 celebration of the birthday of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., who was assassinated in 1968. Specialists in terrorism and criminal psychologists say whoever sent the bombs, if not caught, is likely to strike again after police and media attention lessens. ``What holds an organization like this together, if it is an organization, is they are action-oriented people. Without action, the organization disintegrates,'' said Brian Jenkins, a consultant on terrorism and managing director at Kroll Associates, a Los Angeles-based international investigative firm. ``You could see an attack next month or six months from now,'' he said in a telephone interview. William L. Waugh, an associate professor of public administration at Georgia State University who specializes in international terrorism, said some terrorist groups seek mainly to spread fear, and this one may use continued threats as its means of operation. ``Standard terrorism creates a credible threat, and after a while only the threat makes people nervous,'' he said. ``After a while they can wait longer and longer'' between violent acts. Dr. Dave Davis, a forensic psychiatrist who works for the Secret Service, said the letter to WAGA reflected a mind filled with anger, low self-esteem and a willingness to kill for attention. ``He's really a sicko. If I had to take a guess right off I'd say he was a paranoid person,'' Davis told The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. The experts said a small group probably was involved, if the bombings were the work of more than one person. ``Most times, you become a terrorist because you have a cause and nobody will listen to you,'' said Bill Bailey, president of Threat Management Associates, a Houston security service. ``They're politically way out of the mainstream. If they do catch them, they probably will fit around the dining room table.'' In addition to the fatal bombs, a bomb was intercepted in Jacksonville, Fla., where Vance was involved in a desegregation case, and another in Atlanta. All carried Georgia postmarks. The letter to WAGA had an Atlanta postmark, as did follow-up letters to victims. ``The likelihood, with the way it's been organized, is that they're a splinter from another group,'' Waugh said. ``These are ideas that don't just come out of the blue.'' Pat Clark, director of the Klanwatch operations at the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Ala., said Friday that the organization has identified more than 230 hate groups in the United States, but none calls itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System. Jenkins said the theme and language of the letter reflected racism and xenophobia common to the Ku Klux Klan and its spinoffs. Klan groups have vehemently denied involvement. Jenkins said the only way to stop the threats was to catch those involved. ``One thing we've learned from dealing with terrorists is we can displace the risk, spread it around,'' Jenkins said. ``But somebody has to go out there and apprehend the people and put them out of business.''
